page.title: 03Customs in Wychnor
page.content: The lords of the manor of Wychnor in the middles ages were the de Sommerville family. According to tradition they were granted the manor by John of Gaunt on condition that they provided a flitch (side) of bacon to any couple living on their own estates who could prove that they had not argued during their first year of marriage. There were three couples who claimed the flitch, but two of them were found to be lieing. This custom is recorded on the fireplace of the present Wychnor Hall. The fireplace is one of the few remnants of the old hall and is dated 1337. There is a wooden, life-sized carving of the flitch, with the words of the story, above the fire-place. The custom fell into disuse in the 16th century through lack of claimants.
